prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(8-7) and 13 CO(8-7) in the Cloverleaf
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Integration time estimated to get a 5 sigma detection of the 13 CO (8-7) line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Here we seek to map the [CI] 370 and 609 micron lines, CO(7-6), CO(8-7), CO(11-10), and CO(13-12), and the isotopologue 13CO(8-7). Table 1 lists the expected line fluxes from the literature as well as our expected peak line intensity per beam assuming a 0.5" or 0.7" ALMA synthesized beam, line emission uniformly distributed over the Cloverleaf, and 500 km/s line widths. The later is a reasonable average line width based on the current observations (e.g., Weiss et al. 2005, Riechers et al. 2011). We determine the size of the Cloverleaf by calculating the emission area of our ALMA Cycle 0 120 micron continuum map. For the 0.5" and 0.7 " beams there are ~10 and 5 beams covering the source, respectively. We use the 1-sigma upper limit from Bradford et al. (2009) as the estimate for the CO isotopologue line strength. For the high-J transitions we assume that the Cloverleaf does in fact have a higher-excitation component, similar to that of NGC 1068 (Hailey-Dunsheath et al. 2012; Spinoglio et al. 2012), and scale the CO(1-0) line flux from Riechers et al. (2011) according to the relative line ratios in NGC 1068 (see Fig. 3). We then seek an integration time to detect these lines at the 5-sigma level. If as suggested by Riechers et al. (2011) there is only a single low-excitation component in the Cloverleaf, we would expect the CO(11-10) intensity to be only ~3 mJy over the entire source (~0.3 mJy per 0.5" beam; Band 7). By integrating over the entire source, we would expect a 1-sigma RMS in our proposed CO(11-10) observations of 0.25 mJy, giving us a 12-sigma detection of even the lowest possible CO(11-10) line flux. If it is the case that the Cloverleaf has no higher excitation component, then the CO(13-12) line would be undetectable in our proposed observations; however, our requested integration times are set by the strength of the [NII] line, and the CO(13-12) happens to fall in the upper side band (Band 8), effectively observing the line for free. Similarly both the 13CO and 12CO(8-7) transitions (Band 6) are observed simultaneously, as are the [CI] 370 micron and CO(7-6) lines (also Band 6). In the later Band 6 spectral configuration, we have set the spare basebands to cover the HCN(9-8) and HCO+(9-8) transition, potentially providing additional constraints on the high density gas in the Cloverleaf for no additional time.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO(7-6), CI 370, HCN 9-8, HCO+ 9-8 micron in the Cloverleaf
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Integration time estimated to get a 5 sigma detection of [CI] 370

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CI 609 micron line in the Cloverleaf

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: [NII] 205 micron and CO(13-12) in the Cloverleaf
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Integration time estimated to get a 5 sigma detection of the [NII] 205 micron line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high resolution mapping of several CO lines and atomic fine structure lines in the z = 2.56 gravitationally lensed quasar HH1413+11 (the Cloverleaf). The Cloverleaf is one of a small number of z~2 galaxies with a well-sampled CO ladder, complete from CO(1-0) to CO(9-8). While the existing CO observations are consistent with a single temperature/density model, this result may be coincidental if differential lensing is boosting emission from warmer gas. High-resolution ALMA observations will allow us to (a) determine how strongly differential lensing is affecting excitation analyses, (b) determine if there exists a previously undetected XDR component, and (c) constrain spatial variation in the gas physical conditions (temperature, density, etc.). We ask for a total of 14.3 hours in a combination of Bands 4, 6, 7, and 8 to observe four CO lines, one CO isotopologue, and three atomic fine structure lines at 0.5-0.7" resolution. Our proposed spatially resolved CO and fine structure line observations, when coupled with our existing low-J CO maps, will allow us to examine the local variations of the multi-phase ISM in one of the most well-known high-z quasar host galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University

Laboratory for Millimeter-Wave Astronomy, Maryland, University of
Division of Physics Mathematics and Astronomy, California Institute of Technology
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
